profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-01-13T08:36-0500

did.unittitle: Fairfield Families Collection

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: There are no restrictions on access to this collection.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Use of the material requires compliance with the Fairfield Museum and History Center regulations.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Item, Collection Title, Collection number (Box #, Folder #). Fairfield Museum and History Center, Fairfield, Connecticut.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Information for some families can be found in their section of the finding aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This artificial collection contains small collections from families as well as individuals in Fairfield. They are arranged alphabetically in folders with later accruals in later boxes and not in alphabetical order. Consult the finding aid for the location of a particular family.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: This collection was originally processed by Martha Rockwell in January 1985 and continues to be added to.

did.unittitle: Adams Family Papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of correspondence, deeds and mortgage papers concerning land and buildings at 1975 Mill Plain Road sold by Russell Lombard to Arthur and Frederick Adams who ran a wholesale florist business there. This property was sold to Joseph Neverdousky in 1960.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: These items are from accession number L87.June.2

Angevine, Evelyn Papers--Merritt Parkway Advisory Committee Records

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: These items from the estate of Evelyn Angeline were found among the records of the Sasquanaug Association and donated to the Historical Society by that organization since they did not directly document their own work. Angeline served on the Merritt Parkway Commission in the 1950's and continued her interest in the scenic roadway through preservation efforts in the 1970's and 1980's. The records Angevine saved are very scattered. This series comes from accession number L1998.20.

did.unittitle: Flyer, memoranda, newspaper clipping
Anti/Halasz Family Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Julius Halasz immigrated to the United States from Hungary in 1906. He married Maria (Mary) Anti in 1912. Mary immigrated from Hungary in 1906 with her father Janos (John), mother Katalin (Katherine) Varga Anti and her brother Janos (John). The spelling of the Anti family name was later changed to Antey due to the negative connotation of Anti.
Julius and Mary built a house at 82-84 Dalewood Avenue in the Grasmere area.

Julius worked at Casco and kept a garden in a lot on Ardmore Street. He enjoyed making his own wine from the grapes he grew. He was killed by a car while crossing the street in 1952. He had just left the Ash Creek Saloon after having a night cap.
All the family members are buried at Mountain Grove Cemetery.
All biographical information is courtesy of the donor of the collection, Katherine E. Antey Philbrook whose grandparents were Janos (John) and Katherine.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: The wax flower bridal headdress worn by Mary Anti Halasz at her wedding is in the museum collections.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The items in this collection are from accession number L2006.12.

Arens, Egmont Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Mr. Egmont Arens, who owned waterfront property in Southport at 273 Harbor Rd., proposed the construction of a swimming pool and sea wall, and later a floating dock into the Mill River. His correspondents included the U.S. Engineer Office and the Connecticut Flood Control and Water Policy Commission. Plans were drawn by Andrew Huntington and Thomas Currie.

Barnum, P. T. Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: P. T. Barnum (1810-1891) was born in Bethel, CT. Although he is most famous for his circuses and museums, he was also a member of the Connecticut legislature, a bank president, Mayor of Bridgeport, a real estate dealer, newspaper editor and general entrepreneur. He settled in Bridgeport, CT in 1848 in an area which was at that time part of Fairfield.

Brett, George Platt Sr. Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: George Platt Brett (1858-1936) was born in London. He became president of the Macmillan Publishing Co. in New York and moved to Greenfield Hill in Fairfield where he maintained an outstanding pinetum on Congress St.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The items in this series come from accession number L88.Jan.2.

Burr, Harriet E. Papers
Autograph album
did.materialspec: From internal evidence, the owner of the autograph album appears to be Harriet E. Burr, daughter of William Burr and Catherine Burr Sherwood. The signatures and poems in the album were inscribed by family members and friends, the majority of whom lived in Connecticut and New Jersey. Harriet also pasted in a signature of "Silus B. Sherwood, 1828", possibly taken from a letter.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Victoria and August Busat lived on Tunxis Hill in Fairfield in the 1940's.

Callender Family Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Thomas Loring Callender was married to Esther Sayre (1795-1855), daughter of James Sayre and Eunice Dennie. Her first husband was Moses Judah who died around 1830. Judah and Callender was a lock and hardware business in New York City.

did.unittitle: Letters to Thomas Callender, business and personal
Letters to Mrs. Thomas Callender, New York City from Elizabeth Hull, Fairfield, CT are of local interest
Chapman Family Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Daniel Chapman (1688/9-1741) married Grissel Dennie (1696/7-1754). Their son Dennie Chapman married Desire Lovel and they had sons Lovel Chapman, b. 1755, and Dennie Chapman, b. 1757.

Chauncey Family Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Chauncey family was from Stratford, CT. Charles Chauncey was a minister and president of Harvard College.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: This series was a gift of Mr. and Mrs. C. H. R. Godfrey probably in the 1950's.

Child, Frank Samuel Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Frank Samuel Child (1854-1922) was minister of the First Church of Christ, Fairfield, CT from 1888 to 1920 and one of the founders of the Fairfield Historical Society in 1902.

did.unittitle: Addresses

Clark Family Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Cameron Clark, Jr. attended Yale and upon graduation joined the Navy. He was assigned to the USS Prairie State and then to the sub chase training center in Miami, FL. In January 1945 he transferred to Newport, RI, assigned to the USS Parmina and saw the end of the War in Tokyo Harbor. He was mustered out of the service in 1946.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The items in this series come from accession numbers L88.Jan.2 and L90.Jul.1.

did.unittitle: Postcards to Cameron Clark (b. 1992) and his sister Cordelia Clark (b. 1925) from Ellsworth Merwin (1913-1946). These postcards were written on a western trip during July, August and September 1935.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Photocopies of the cards are on the library shelf, Clark-Merwin Postcard collection (808.86932 c592).

Corbusier, Alfred B. Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: John Peniston Corbusier, a furniture maker, was born in 1792 in Bermuda and died in Southport, CT in 1877. His son, Alfred Bascomb Corbusier, was born in New York City in 1823 and lived in Bridgeport, CT. He was a furniture varnisher and later a dancing instructor.

Daily, Thomas A. Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Thomas A. Daily was born in 1956 and ran as the Republican nominee for State Representative from the 134th District. He lost the election.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Items in this series are from accession number L90.Dec.15.

Donaldson, Chase Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Chase Donaldson was born in California to Dr. Frank Donaldson and Ethel Sprague. He was the great-grandson of Lincoln’s Secretary of the Treasury Salmon P. Chase. He married Elinor Thompson on 14 June 1930. He was previously widowed with three children. Elinor was born in Delaware and attended Miss Porter’s School in Farmington.

After marrying the couple lived in the Oliver T. Sherwood house on Pequot Road (now number 683) from approximately 1933-1938. Chase also maintained a home in New York City where he worked as a broker.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: The items in this collection were found by the donor during a 2008 renovation of the Oliver T. Sherwood home. They are from accession number L2008.6.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Rev. Andrew Eliot was born in Boston in 1744 and died in Fairfield in 1805. He was educated at Harvard and ordained the pastor of the First Church, Fairfield in 1774.

Gallagher, William D. Diary

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: William D. Gallagher (1845-1884) was the son of Dennis and Mary J. Banks Gallagher. William lived and worked on his father's farm and documented his activities in his diary. In addition to farming and visiting, he also kept a record of births, deaths, birthdays and anniversaries of friends and acquaintances.

did.unittitle: Gilbert, Burr papers
Appointment as Brigadier General, Connecticut militia
Bond
Gilden, Joseph Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Joseph Gilden, born in Stamford, CT, was a practicing chiropodist in Fairfield. He was one of the founding members of the Fairfield Lion's Club. The fishing license he was issued in 1943 includes his photograph and finger print, a means of reducing possible spying in the early years of World War II.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: These items were donated by Joseph himself in May of 1996 (L96May40).

Havard, Aline Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Aline Havard was a local author, crippled with arthritis since high school, who lived on the Old Post Road. She wrote many children's stories. She died in Towson, MD. Further information is available in the folder.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See the collection for Aline Havard's book The Two Runaways (813.54 H383T)

Judson Family Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: David Judson (1757-1841) was born in Stratford and graduated from Yale in 1778. He settled in Fairfield and married Esther Bulkley in 1783. He was a storekeeper, postmaster, trustee of The Academy and founder of the first public library.

Kent (Hazard) Family Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: John Hazard (1719-1771) of Fairfield married Mary Wakeman in 1752. Mary was remarried to Moss Kent of Fredericksburg, NY. John Hazard owned several houses in Fairfield and Southport and was believed to be a Tory.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Dr. Samuel Osgood (1812-1880) was a Unitarian minister in several churches, living in Fairfield only in the summer. His daughter, Mabel Osgood Wright (1859-1934) was an author and naturalist. She lived in Fairfield and was a close friend of Annie B. Jennings.

did.unittitle: Sherwood, John Henry Papers

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: These items were donated by David S. Huntington in October 1996 (L96.36).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: John Henry Sherwood (1825-1918), the son of Hull Sherwood and Caroline Burr, was a farmer who resided at Greenfield Hill. His brother David H. Sherwood (1829-1892) also farmed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John's correspondence includes a letter from P. T. Barnum concerning preparations for the upcoming agricultural fair (1 Sept. 1851). Other letters relate to farming or family news. Evidently John was active in the Fairfield County Agricultural Society--the collection includes a copy of the society's constitution; lists of committee members; statements of crops raised by Hull Sherwood and Sons, 1850, attested to by David Sherwood; essays on the benefits of agricultural societies and a report on feed crops. The genealogy notes primarily concern the Shelton family. The school records encompass a note, 1867, from Anna Godfrey to Dimon Bradley, both of Easton, concerning the end of school terms and who appears to be an attendance record.

did.unittitle: Correspondence to John Sherwood
Fairfield County Agricultural Society records
Genealogy notes, school records, and voting list

Tomlinson, Gideon Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Gideon Tomlinson was born in Stratford, Conn. in 1780. He attended Yale, class of 1802. In 1807 he married Sarah Bradley of Greenfield Hill, where the couple settled. Tomlinson practiced law and held public office, including the U.S. Senate and Governor of the State of Connecticut.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: This collection is made up of a few donations. L83.May.2, L82.Feb.2 (Pequot Library), L96.Jan.3 (Bob Walter).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See Ms 33 for Clarina Brewster's will and Yale Biographies and Annals, 1792-1805 for a biography of Gideon Tomlinson.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Worden (Wordin) family members were prominent businessmen in Bridgeport, Conn. William Wordin, Jr. married Dorcas Cook, explaining the genealogical notes on the Cooks. The materials in Folder S do not appear to be related to the Worden or Cook families. For more information on the Wordens see Orcutt’s History of Stratford and Bridgeport, Connecticut, vol. 2, pp. 925-930.
